section.title: Saving HamQSLer Card Files
section.para: Once a card has been created, it may be saved to be loaded and used at a future time. To do this, select the Cards => File Save or Cards => File Save As... menu items. File Save is only available if the card has previously been saved because the program must know the directory in which you want to save the card.
When you select the Card Save As... menu item, the File Save As dialog, shown below, is displayed.

The dialog opens in the default card files folder. This folder can be set in user preferences. See Setting User Preferences for setting this value. Navigate to the folder where you want to save the card file, enter the name you want to save the file as, and then click on the Save button. The card file will be saved and the dialog will close.

section.title: Loading HamQSLer Card Files
section.para: Once a card has been saved, it can be loaded at a later time by selecting the Cards => Open Card... menu item. This displays the File Open dialog with the default directory set to the default card files folder. See the image below:
Navigate to the directory containing the card file you want to open, and either click on the file and then the Open button, or double-click on the file.

tip.para: Keep all of your card related files (card files, images, logos, etc.) in the hamqsler directory or create subdirectories for each file type. That way, all of the files needed for your cards are located in one place so they are easy to back up and to move to another location.

In the past, as Microsoft released new versions of Windows, they sometimes changed the location of the My Directories folder. This occurred, for example, when Windows Vista was released, and people who upgraded from Windows XP ore earlier had problems with hard-coded paths.

If you want to reload the saved card or cards every time you restart the program, check the "Reload Card Files on Startup" checkbox in the User Preferences. See the User Preferences chapter for more information.

section.title: Moving and Converting QslDesignAndPrint Files
section.para: QslDesignAndPrint card files are normally stored in the QslDnP subdirectory of your My Documents directory. You may also have stored other related files such as images, logos, and possibly ADIF files in QslDnP.

HamQSLer uses the hamqsler subdirectory in My Documents. To ease the transition from QslDesignAndPrint to HamQSLer, a move and convert tool has been included in HamQSLer. This tool performs two tasks:

listitem.para: All files except log files, card files, and the user preferences file are copied from a user selected source directory to a user specified destination directory. These files have the extensions .xqsl, .xml, .log, and .log-old.
Card files are converted from QslDesignAndPrint format to HamQSLer format and copied to the destination directory and its subdirectories.

section.para: The following files are not copied or converted: ...\Samples\text2.adi, ...\Samples\moonbasin.jpg, and ...\Samples\sample.xqsl. These three files are used in the QslDesignAndPrint getting started tutorial; a different set of files is used in the HamQSLer getting started tutorial.

To copy and convert your QslDesignAndPrint related files, select the Tools => Import QslDesignAndPrint Files menu item. This opens a Browse For Folder dialog. Select the directory containing the files you want to copy and convert, then click the OK button. Another Browse For Folder dialog will open; use this dialog to select the destination directory, and click the OK button. Copying and conversion will begin.

If one or more errors occurs when copying files from the source directory to the destination directory, the following message box will be displayed, and as noted, the file or files that could not be copied are listed in the log file along with the reason why.

If no files were copied, either because the source directory was empty, or because the files in the directory had already been copied to the destination directory, the message box shown below is displayed.
If the source directory contains no card files, or if there were errors detected while converting every card file, then the following message box is displayed as a warning.

If an image in a QslDesignAndPrint card file references an image file in the source directory, then the location of the image file is changed to the destination directory. If any image file cannot be located, then the message box shown below is displayed, and you are given the choice between trying to locate the file yourself or deleting the image.

figure.title: Image File Not Found Message Box

section.para: If a font cannot be located, it is replaced by the first font in the installed fonts list. See the caution below related to fonts.

When all files have been moved and all card files have been converted, the text "Files have been copied and card files converted. See log file for details." is displayed in the status bar at the bottom of HamQSLer's main window. The log file contains a message for every file copied, every card file converted, every image replaced, every font that could not be found, and every error that was detected during the copy and conversion tasks.

caution.para: HamQSLer uses a different graphical user interface than QslDesignAndPrint to draw cards. In some cases, font face names are different; if your card file references one of these font face names, then the card will not display text in your selected font. The font will be replaced by the first font in the installed fonts list. You may of course change the font face at any time while the card is in design mode.

QslDesignAndPrint used Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF) to print and display cards. HamQSLer uses Windows Forms libraries for printing and displaying cards. There are two potential differences between these libraries as related to fonts:

listitem.para: WPF enumerates all fonts that are installed on your computer. Windows forms only enumerates installed fonts that are located in your ...\Windows\Fonts directory.
There may be small differences in names between the list of installed fonts returned by WPF and by Windows Forms. This only affects a few font names.

caution.para: For these reasons, one or more of the fonts on your QslDesignAndPrint cards may be replaced by the first font in the Windows Forms installed fonts list during the conversion process.

QslDesignAndPrint supports three font weights: normal, bold, and black. HamQSLer only supports normal and bold. For most font faces used in QslDesignAndPrint, black is simply displayed as bold. The one obvious font face for which there is a black font weight is Arial.

An Arial Black font is available on the Internet, but it does not look like Arial with a font weight of black. An alternative to Arial Black is Helvetica Black. You may purchase Helvetica fonts, but they are not available free of charge, and will only be available on your computer if another application has loaded them.
An alternative font face with thicker characters is Verdana, although character shapes are different from Arial.

section.title: Creating a New Card
section.para: A new card may be created by selecting the Cards => New menu item. This opens another submenu from which to select the card size and orientation that you want. At this time, there are three card sizes available:

listitem.para: Bureau sized card in landscape mode (5.5 inches wide by 3.5 inches high, or 139.7 mm wide by 88.9 mm high). This is the standard size for QSL cards and is the size preferred by all QSL bureaus. There are three known suppliers of perforated cardstock for this size of card. See the Outputting Cards chapter for more information.

5.5 inches wide by 4.25 inches wide in landscape mode (139.7 mm wide by 107.95 mm high). Four of these cards may be printed in a two by two layout on US Letter sized card stock. A number of micro-perforated cardstocks are available in this size. See the Outputting Cards chapter for more information.
6 inches wide by 4 inches high in landscape mode (152.4 mm wide by 101.6 mm high). This corresponds to standard 4 inch by 6 inch or 10 cm by 15 cm photopaper.

section.para: Select the menu item for the card size that you want. The new card will be displayed in a new tab in the main window; this tab displays the card in design mode in the panel on the left, and a properties panel on the right. If you set up the various text items properties in User Preferences, as outlined in the Setting User Preferences chapter, then a card similar to the image below will be displayed. The card in this image is bureau sized. If you select a different size card, then that size of card is displayed.

figure.title: New Bureau Sized Card When First Created

section.para: The tab header contains the text "New Card" and the window title is "HamQSLer - New Card". Once you have changed one of the card properties, the tab header will change to "*New Card", and the window title will change to "HamQSLer - New Card - Modified" to show that one or more changes have been made to the card. When you save the card, the tab header will contain the name of the file that you saved the card to, and the window title will contain "HamQSLer - full path to card file.
Again when you modify the card further, an asterisk ("*") will be prepended to the tab header, and " - Modified" will be appended to the window title.

The properties panel on the right side of the card tab contains default printer and print properties for the card, or card item specific properties when a card item is selected. Card default printer and print properties are discussed in the Outputting Cards chapter and therefore will not be mentioned further here.
Cards that are designed using HamQSLer may contain:

listitem.para: A background image.
Any number of secondary images.
Any number of text items.
Zero or one Qsos Box which contains QSO information.

section.para: A new card contains no background or secondary images; three text items: callsign, name and QTH, and a salutation; and a Qsos Box. Any item on a card may be deleted from the card, and any item may be added to the card. Background image is a special case. The actual image may be cleared, but the background image item is still maintained as an item on the card. The Qsos Box is also a special case. Only one Qsos Box is permitted on a card, so it is only possible to add a Qsos Box if the original Qsos Box has been deleted.
The following sections deal with the properties of each card item type, but first we will discuss card design related menu items and then highlighting and selecting card items.

section.title: Card Design Related Menus and Menu Items
Card Design Context Menu
section.para: The card design context menu, shown below, is displayed by clicking the right mouse button anywhere within the card design panel. The menu items that are enabled and disabled are determined by the placement of the cursor when the mouse button was clicked and on a number of design conditions. For example, the Clear Background Image menu item is only enabled if there is a background image.
This table shows the menu items and their actions.

table.title: Card Design Context Menu Items and Actions

row.entry: Selects the highlighted card item to allow editing of the item's properties. See Highlighting and Selecting Card Items for more information.
Deselects the selected card item. See Highlighting and Selecting Card Items for more information.
Adds a new secondary image to the card and selects it for editing. See Adding Secondary Images for more information.
Adds a new text item to the card. See Adding New Text Items for more information.
Adds a new Qsos Box to the card. See Adding a Qsos Box for more information.
Deletes the selected card item from the card. See Deleting a Card Item for more information.
Clears the background image. See Clearing the Background Image for more information.

section.title: Edit Dropdown Menu
section.para: The image above shows the open Edit dropdown menu. The table shows the card design related menu items and their actions.

table.title: Card Design Related Edit Dropdown Menu Items and Actions

row.entry: Adds a new secondary image to the card and selects it for editing. See Adding Secondary Images for more information.
Adds a new text item to the card. See Adding New Text Items for more information.
Adds a new Qsos Box to the card. See Adding a Qsos Box for more information.
Deletes the selected card item from the card. See Deleting a Card Item for more information.
Clears the background image. See Clearing the Background Image for more information.

section.title: Select Dropdown Menu
section.para: The image below shows a sample dropdown menu. The contents of the menu above the separator (the line) changes depending on image and text item properties. For example, the first item in the menu is "Background" if there is no background image, and the file name of the background image if there is one. Similarly, each secondary image has a menu item: "Image" if there is no image loaded, and the file name of the image if there is one loaded. Menu items for each text item contains the first 10 characters of the design text for the text item.
The following table shows the menu items and their actions. See Highlighting and Selecting Card Items for more information on selecting card items.

table.title: Card Design Related Select Dropdown Menu Items and Actions

row.entry: Selects the background image. This menu item only appears when there is no image specified for the background.
Selects the secondary image. This menu item only appears for secondary images that do not have an image file specified.
Selects the background or secondary image item that has this file name specified.
Selects the text item whose design text starts with this text.
Selects the Qsos Box card item. This menu item only appears if there is a Qsos Box on the card.

section.title: Highlighting and Selecting Card Items
section.para: When you move the mouse cursor over any card item on the card, that card item is highlighted or outlined with an orange dashed line. For example, the image below shows the salutation text item highlighted because the mouse cursor is over it.

As mentioned earlier, the background image is a special card item. If there is a background image on the card, that image is highlighted when the cursor moves over it; if there is no background image present, then the card is outlined. This is done so that you know there is no background image for the card and so that the background may be selected.

Card items may overlap. When you move the mouse cursor over the area where these card items overlap, the card item with higher precedence is highlighted. The list below shows the precedence of card items from highest to lowest:

simplelist.member: Text items in the reverse of the order that they were created.
Secondary images in the reverse of the order that they were created.

section.para: A card item may be selected in one of two ways:

listitem.para: Move the cursor over the card item to highlight it, then click the right mouse button to open the card item context menu. Select the "Select Highlighted Item" menu item from the context menu. The contents of this context menu is discussed in the Card Design Context Menu section, above.
Select the card item from the Select dropdown menu. More information about this menu is provided in the Select Dropdown Menu section, above.

section.para: When a card item has been selected, the card item is outlined by a dark blue dashed outline, and the properties for the card item are displayed in the card properties panel. Editing of card item properties is discussed in a number of sections that follow.
The image below shows the salutation text item that was highlighted in the image above once the item has been selected.

section.title: Deselecting Selected Card Items
section.para: A card item may be deselected in either of the following ways:

listitem.para: Open the card item context menu and select the "Deselect Item" menu item.
Select the "None" menu item from the Select dropdown menu.

section.para: When the card item is deselected, it is no longer highlighted by a dark blue dashed line.

section.title: Deleting a Card Item
section.para: A card item must be selected before it can be deleted. There are two ways to delete a card item:

listitem.para: Select the "Delete Selected Item" menu item from the card items context menu.
Select "Delete Selected Item" from the Edit dropdown menu.

caution.para: Once a card item has been deleted, it cannot be restored; your only option is to add a card item (secondary image, text item, or Qsos Box) to the card and modify its properties to match the old card item.

section.title: Adding Secondary Images
section.para: A secondary image may be added to a card in either of the following ways:

listitem.para: Select "Add Image" from the card items context menu.
Select "Add Image" from the Edit dropdown menu.

section.para: The new secondary image item is initially created as a 1 inch by 1 inch (25.4 mm by 25.4 mm) square that is centered on the card. This card item is selected, and the secondary image properties panel is displayed in the card properties panel to the right of the card design panel. This card item may be moved and resized at any time. See the Moving and Resizing Card Items section below.

tip.para: If your card does not contain a background image, use the background image item for the first image on your card. This reduces the size of the card file and improves program performance during display and printing operations.

caution.para: As stated, when a new secondary image is added to a card, it is centered on the card. Because of the order in which card items are drawn (see the precedence order in Highlighting and Selecting Card Items, above), the image may not be visible. Move any other images, text items, and the Qsos Box to see the image.

section.title: Adding New Text Items
section.para: A new text item may be added to a card in the following ways:

listitem.para: Select "Add Text Item" from the card item context menu.
Select "Add Text Item" from the Edit dropdown menu.

section.para: The new text item is initially positioned with the top left corner of the card item located at the center of the card. The text item has the following properties when it is created:

listitem.para: Text is "Text Item".
Font face is the default text font face that was defined when the card was first created. See the Setting User Preferences chapter for information on setting this default property.
The font size is 12 points.

section.para: The text item may be moved at any time. See the Moving and Resizing Card Items section below.
When the text item is created, it is automatically selected and the text item properties panel is displayed in the card properties panel.

caution.para: As stated, when a new text item is added to a card, it is positioned at the center of the card. Because of the order in which card items are drawn (see the precedence order in Highlighting and Selecting Card Items, above), the text item may not be visible. Move any text items and the Qsos Box to see the new text item.

section.title: Adding a Qsos Box
section.para: A Qsos Box can be added to a card if the original Qsos Box was deleted. There are two ways to add a Qsos Box to a card:

listitem.para: Select "Add Qsos Box" from the card items context menu.
Select "Add Qsos Box" from the Edit dropdown menu.

section.para: The Qsos Box is initially positioned with its upper edge at the center of the card. The box width is set at 90% of the width of the card, and the box is positioned horizontally at the center of the card. The Qsos Box may be moved and resized at any time. See the Moving and Resizing Card Items section below.
When the Qsos Box is added to the card, it is selected and the Qsos Box properties panel is displayed in the card properties panel.

tip.para: Text in the Qsos Box is intially displayed in the Qsos Box default font face. See the Setting User Preferences chapter for information on changing this property.

Text that is displayed in the Qsos Box (confirming text, column headers, and the text printed in the QSL column) is defined in the user preferences. See the Setting User Preferences chapter for information on setting these text values.

caution.para: When a new card is created, the confirming text, column headers, and the text that is printed in the QSL column, are copied from the user preferences file to the card file. This text remains fixed for this card.

section.title: Clearing the Background Image
section.para: The background image may be cleared in one of two ways:

listitem.para: Select "Clear Background Image" from the card items context menu.
Select "Clear Background Image" from the Edit dropdown menu.

section.para: If the background image item was selected before the image was cleared, the item remains selected; otherwise it remains unselected.

section.title: Moving and Resizing Card Items
section.para: Once a card item has been selected, it may be moved or resized. All card items may be moved using the mouse cursor. Images may also be resized using the mouse cursor. Text items may only be resized by changing the text, font, font size, and bold and italic properties of the text items. The width of the Qsos Box may be changed using the mouse, but its height and its minimum width are determined by a number of Qsos Box properties including the font, the font size, the columns shown, the column headers, the date format selected, and the maximum number of Qsos that may be printed on the card. See the Setting Qsos Box Properties section for information on changing these properties.

When the mouse cursor is moved over a selected card item, the cursor will change to one of the cursors shown in the table below. The cursor that is displayed is determined by the position of the cursor in the card item and the type of card item that is selected. To move or resize a card item, press and hold the left mouse button and drag the mouse to move the cursor to a new location. Release the mouse button to complete the operation. The card item will move or be resized as the the mouse is dragged.

row.entry: This is the move cursor. It is displayed for all card items when the mouse cursor is inside the selected card item. Press and hold the left mouse button and drag the mouse to move the card item. The card item moves in the direction and the amount that the mouse cursor is dragged. Release the left mouse button when the card item is positioned where you want it.

This cursor is only displayed when the mouse cursor is moved over the top left or bottom right corner of a selected background or secondary image. Press and hold the left mouse button and drag the mouse towards the center of the image to reduce the size of the image. To enlarge the image, press the left mouse button and drag the mouse away from the center of the image. Release the left mouse button when the resize operation is completed. The opposite corner of the image remains in a fixed position. The aspect ratio (the ratio of image width to image height) of the image is not changed.

This cursor is only displayed when the mouse cursor is moved over the top right or bottom left corner of a selected background or secondary image. Press and hold the left mouse button and drag the cursor towards the center of the image to decrease the size of the image. Move the mouse cursor away from the center of the image to enlarge the image. Release the left mouse button when the resize operation is complete. The opposite corner of the image remains fixed. The aspect ratio of the image is not changed.

This cursor is only displayed when the mouse cursor is moved over the left or right edges of the Qsos Box. Press and hold the left mouse button and drag the mouse to the left or right to change the width of the Qsos Box. Release the left mouse button when the Qsos Box resize operation is complete. The Qsos Box width may be reduced until it reaches its minimum size after which further mouse movements are ignored.

section.title: Setting Card Item Properties
section.para: The methods for setting some card item properties are common between two or more card item types. For example, the method used to specify the image file to load for background and secondary images is the same. Similarly, the method for setting the color of a text item is the same as setting the color of the Qsos Box. These common methods are discussed here before the setting of specific card item properties is discussed.

section.title: Setting an Image File Name
section.para: This method is common between background images and secondary images. Setting the image file name for the background image of a card will be used as the example here.
The image below shows the background image properties panel. This panel is displayed in the card items properties panel when the background image item is selected.

This image shows the background image properties panel when there is no image. To load an image, click the button labeled "...". This displays the File Open dialog in the default images folder. Navigate to the directory containing the image that you want to use as the card background and select the image. The dialog will close and the image will display centered on the card. The initial size and position of the image depends on whether you are loading a background image or a secondary image. The location and size of the image is specified in the appropriate section below.

tip.para: The default images folder is maintained in the user preferences file. See the Setting User Preferences chapter for information on setting this value.

section.para: When you load an image, the path to the image file is displayed in the text box below the "..." button in the image properties panel. The image below shows the background image properties panel after the background image used in the Getting Started tutorial has been loaded.

figure.title: Background Image Properties With Sample Image Loaded

section.para: There are two relative path specifiers: $MyDocs$ is a reference to the current user's My Documents directory; $hamqslerFolder$ is a references to the hamqsler directory in the current user's My Documents directory. If the image file is located anywhere other than in My Documents, hamqsler, or a subdirectory of these directories, then the full path name is specified. The path in the image above specifies that the image file is located at ...\My Documents\hamqsler\Samples\sample.jpg.

section.title: Setting Colors
section.para: The color of text in text items as well as the color of text and lines in the Qsos Box may be changed. The current color of an item is shown in a button in the card item's properties panel. For example, the image below shows the text color label and button on the text item properties panel.

In this case, the text in the text item is black as shown inside the button. Clicking on the button opens the color picker dialog which is shown in the following image. The image shows the color picker as it would be if you had clicked the text color button above. Note that the black color swatch in the Basic colors section is selected, matching the color in the text color button. If the previously set color does not exactly match one of the colors in the Basic color swatches, then the first color swatch is highlighted, even though that color does not match.
There are several ways to select a color:

listitem.para: Click on a color swatch in the Basic colors section. Note the ColorSolid swatch, and the settings of the Hue, Saturation and Luminance text boxes, and the Red, Green, and Blue boxes. The displayed values match the selected color.

Click on a location in the color rainbow, then move the slider located to the right of the rainbow to adjust the luminance of the selected color. Note that the Hue, Saturation, and Luminance values, as well as the Red, Green, and Blue values, change to match the color. The ColorSolid swatch also changes to match.
Enter the Hue, Saturation, and Luminance values directly. Valid values are from 0 to 240.
Enter the Red, Green, and Blue values directly. Valid values range from 0 to 255. You are probably much more familiar with this method of specifying a color than using hue, saturation, and luminance.

section.para: Once you have chosen the color you want, click the OK button to select it. The color picker dialog will close, the color of the button will change to match the chosen color, and the corresponding card item property will change to that color.

tip.para: In the color picker dialog, there is an "Add to Custom Colors" button. If you click on that button, the chosen color will be added to the Custom colors swatches. Custom colors are saved for display the next time that you open the color picker dialog.

section.title: Setting Dropdown Box Values
section.para: In a dropdown box, the list of acceptable values is shown when you click on the dropdown box. There are several ways to select a value:

listitem.para: Click anywhere in the dropdown box to open it. Select the value you want by clicking on it. The dropdown list closes and the selected value is displayed in the box. If the list is long, it will not all be displayed in the dropdown. To scroll up the list, place the mouse cursor at the top of the dropdown; to scroll down the list, place the mouse cursor at the bottom of the dropdown. Alternatively, you may scroll using the mouse wheel.

Using the keyboard, tab until the dropdown box is selected. This is indicated by a dashed line around the text in the dropdown box. Use the up and down arrow keys, or the left and right arrow keys, to move to the previous and next values in the list.

Using the keyboard, tab until the dropdown box is selected. Press the keys matching the first few letters of the value you want to select. As you press the keys, the first item in the dropdown list that matches that set of keys is selected. Keep pressing keys until the value you want is selected.

Using the keyboard, tab until the dropdown box is selected. Press the first character of the value you want to select. The first value in the list that starts with that character is selected. Pressing the same key will select the second value that starts with that character. Keep pressing the key until the value you want is selected. Note: you must not pause between keypresses or the first value in the list will be selected again.

section.title: Setting Combobox Values
section.para: A combobox is a combination of a dropdown box and a text box. A set of values is displayed in a dropdown box, and values not in the dropdown may be entered.

Because a combobox is a dropdown box, all of the methods described in the section above may be used to select a predefined value. You may also enter a value as you would in a text box, using the keyboard.

section.title: Setting Background Image Properties
section.para: The only property for a background image is the image file name. The method for setting this property is described in the Setting an Image File Name section, above.

When you set the image file name for a background image, the image will be sized to completely cover the card; if the aspect ratio of the image is different from the aspect ratio of the card, then the image will extend either to the left and right of the card or the top and bottom of the card. You saw this in the Getting Started tutorial.
You may move and resize the image by following the instructions in the Moving and Resizing Card Items section of this chapter.

section.title: Setting Secondary Image Properties
section.para: The method for specifying the image file name for a secondary image is described in the Setting an Image File Name section above. When the image is displayed for the first time, it is centered on the card, and the shorter of the width and height dimensions of the image is set to 1 inch or 25.4 mm. You may move and resize the image using the instructions in the Moving and Resizing Card Items section in this chapter.

section.title: Setting Text Item Properties
section.para: When a text item is selected, the text item properties panel is displayed in the card properties panel. The image below shows the text item properties panel when the callsign text item is selected.

figure.title: Text Item Properties Panel for Callsign Text Item

section.para: The font used to display the text item is selected using the font dropdown box. See Setting Dropdown Box Values, above for methods to select a font from this dropdown box.

tip.para: Choose a font that is easy to read. In general, proportionally spaced fonts are easier to read than fixed-width fonts. Also, choose a standard serif or sans-serif font; do not use a script or abstract font. As you can see from the table below, Verdana, a proportionally spaced, sans-serif font, and Times New Roman, a proportionally spaced, serif font, are easy to read. Edwardian Script ITC, a script font, and Blackadder ITC, an abstract font, are difficult to read.
Use only one or two font faces per card. You can distinguish different text items by position, font weight, font style, font size, or color.

section.para: Checking and unchecking the Bold checkbox switches between bold and normal font weights.
Checking and unchecking the Italic checkbox switches between italic and normal font styles.

caution.para: Not all font faces support the italic style. In such cases, the text remains displayed in the normal style.

section.para: The font size (in points) may be set using the font size combobox. You may either select a predefined value, or enter a different value. The value entered must be greater than 0; if 0 is entered, the value 1 is actually used. See Setting Combobox Values above for information on using this combobox.
Click on the text color button to open the color picker dialog to select a color for the text. See Setting Colors above for selecting a color using the color picker dialog.
In the image above, the Text groupbox contains a static text box with the text "VA3HJ" and a Macros button. See the Macros chapter for information on using macros.

tip.para: See Appendix C if you want to enter characters that are not available on your keyboard.

section.para: The Check Boxes group box contains a number of properties related to the display of check boxes before and after the text in a text item.
To place a checkbox before the text, check the Before Text checkbox. To place a checkbox after the text, check the After Text checkbox.
To set the thickness of the checkboxes, adjust the Line Thickness slider. The value displayed is in hundredths of an inch.
To change the size of the checkboxes, adjust the Check Box Ratio slider. The value that is displayed is the ratio of the height and and width of the checkboxes to the total height of the text item.

section.title: Setting Qsos Box Properties
section.para: The Qsos Box properties panel, shown in the image below, is displayed in the card properties panel when the Qsos Box is selected.

The default confirming text, that is, the confirming text that is displayed if you have not changed it in user preferences, is "Confirming Two-Way QSOs With callsign via manager". The state of the Show Manager checkbox determines whether the text "via manager" is printed on the card. If the checkbox is checked and the QSOs printed on the card contain a manager field, then the text is printed; if the checkbox is unchecked, then the text is not printed.

tip.para: The confirming text is stored in the user preferences file. See the Setting User Preferences chapter for information on changing this text.

caution.para: The confirming text is saved with the card file when the card is created. The only way to change this text is to change the confirming text item in user preferences, then create a new card.

section.para: The Qsos Box may contain either a band or a frequency column. The column that is printed on the card is controlled by the Show Band Column and Show Freq Column radio buttons. Set the Show Band Column radio button to show a Band column, or set the Show Frequency Column radio button to show a Frequency column.

If, when a QSO is loaded or input, it includes a frequency field and not a band field, a band field that corresponds to the frequency is added to the QSO. If a band field is included in the QSO when loaded or input, but no frequency field is included and the Show Freq Column checkbox is checked, then when the card containing the QSO is printed, a frequency value based on the band field is substituted.

tip.para: The frequency value that is substituted is determined by values stored in the user preferences file. See the Setting User Preferences chapter for information on changing the values that are substituted.

section.para: The Qsos Box may contain an optional QSL column containing text such as "Pse" or "Tnx" for each QSO. Check the Show QSL Column checkbox to include the column; uncheck the checkbox to not include the column. The width of each column in the Qsos Box is adjusted based on the state of this checkbox.

tip.para: The QSL column header text and the text printed for each QSO is set in the user preferences file. See the Setting User Preferences chapter for information on changing the text.

caution.para: The text values are saved in the card file when the card is created and are therefore fixed for the card. A new card must be created if you want to change the text.

section.para: The Date Format dropdown box contains a selection of formats used to print the dates in the date column on the card. The setting also determines the header that is printed for the date column. Select the date format you want from the dropdown box. Methods for selecting a value are discussed in the Setting Dropdown Box Values section.
The following date formats are available:

listitem.para: YYYY-MM-DD. This is one of the ISO 8601 date formats.
DD-MMM-YY. A three character month value is substituted for "MMM" when the date is printed.
DD-MM-YY.

tip.para: The header text that is printed or displayed in the date column is determined by the date format selected. The header text for each format may be set in the user preferences file. See the Setting User Preferences chapter for more information.
The default date format is also set in the user preferences file. See the Setting User Preferences chapter for information on how to set this default value.
The three character month abreviations are saved in the user preferences file. See the Setting User Preferences chapter for information on how to change these values.

caution.para: The header text for each date format is saved in the card file when the card is created. The only way to change these values is to change them in user preferences and then create a new card.

section.para: The value selected in the Max QSOs dropdown box determines the maximum number or QSOs that can be printed on a card. This is also the number of lines for QSOs that are displayed in design mode. The actual number of lines printed in the Qsos Box matches the number of QSOs being printed on the card. If no QSOs are being printed on the card, the QSOs Box that is printed contains an empty line for each of the maximum number of QSOs.

Click the Line and Text Color button to change the color that the Qsos Box lines and text are printed in. This opens a Color Picker dialog to allow selection of a color. See the Setting Colors section for information on how to select a color.
Click the Callsign Color button to set the color that the callsign in the confirming text is printed in. This opens a Color Picker dialog to allow the selection of a color.
Click the Manager Color button to set the color that the "via manager" text in the confirming text is printed in. This opens a Color Picker dialog to allow the selection of the color.

The Font Size dropdown box contains a list of font sizes (in points) that the text in the Qsos Box can be printed in. Select a value using one of the methods described in the Setting Dropdown Box Values section.

tip.para: As described in the Moving and Resizing Card Items section in this chapter, the width of the Qsos Box may be resized. The minimum width for the Qsos Box is determined by the width of the text displayed in each column. The width of the text is determined by the font size that the text is displayed or printed in. Select a smaller font size to reduce the minimum width for the Qsos Box.

section.para: The selected value in the Font dropdown box determines the font face that the text in the Qsos Box is displayed or printed in. Select the font you want to use. The dropdown box contains all of the fonts located in the Fonts system directory that are registered on your computer.

tip.para: A card that uses too many different font faces looks busy and amaterish. Use only one or two font faces on your card. Use different font sizes, font weights, font styles, and colors for text items rather than different font faces to distinguish among the various pieces of information on the card.

section.para: The Qsos Box background has two properties: color and opacity. Click the Background Color button to set the background color. This opens a Color Picker dialog that allows you to select a color. See the Setting Colors section, above, for information on how to select a color.

Once the background color has been set, adjust the Background Opacity slider to set the opacity (reverse of transparency) of the Qsos Box. The lower the opacity value, the more any card items behind the text box show through.

section.title: Ideas For Handling Multiple Choices
section.para: The following subsections discuss different ways that you can handle multiple items. For example, you may have multiple callsigns, operate from multiple QTHs, and may want to QSL a number of QSOs with the same station, some of which you have received QSL cards for and some for which you have not received QSL cards.

section.title: Handling Multiple Callsigns
section.para: There are several ways that you can handle multiple callsigns:

listitem.para: Create a different card for each callsign.

Have a text item with a checkbox for each callsign. Use a pen to check the box for the appropriate callsign. You would have to select only those QSOS for one callsign to use this method, or save your logs for each callsign in a different log file.

For your callsign text item, use an AdifMacro to retrieve the STATION_CALLSIGN field from the QSOs. If your logging program does not log STATION_CALLSIGN, use the OPERATOR field instead. Finally, if the OPERATOR field is not logged, check for the OWNER_CALLSIGN field. Be sure to check the Separate Cards by ADIF Field checkbox for the macro. See the Macros chapter for information on the AdifMacro.

section.title: Handling Multiple QTHs
section.para: There are also several ways to handle multiple QTHs:

listitem.para: Create a different card for each QTH. You would want to use this method if you use different images for each QTH.
Have a text item with a checkbox for each QTH. Use a pen to check the appropriate QTH. You would have to select only those QSOs for one QTH to use this method.

If your logging program uses an application specific field to specify unique QTHs that you operate from, use an AdifMacro in a text item to specify the QTH. Check the Separate Cards by ADIF Field checkbox for the macro. See the Macros chapter for information on the AdifMacro.

section.title: Please QSL Thanks
section.para: Every QSL card should contain either a request for a QSL card from the other station, or a thanks for the card that the other station sent you. HamQSLer provides a number of ways of accomplishing this:

listitem.para: If you only send QSL cards in response to a received card, then add a text item containing the text "Thanks QSL" somewhere on the card.
Add a text item containing the text "Please QSL Thanks" or "Pse QSL Tnx" on the card and use a pen to strike out the "Please" or "Thanks" as appropriate.
Add a text item containing the text "Please QSL Thanks" or "Pse QSL Tnx" with a checkbox at each end. Use a pen to check the box that is appropriate.

An alternative to the item above is to add two text items to the card with a checkbox before each text item. The text for the two text items would be "Pse QSL" and "Tnx QSL" or similar. Use a pen to check the appropriate checkbox.

What if you are QSLing a number of QSOs, some that you received a QSL card for, and some that you did not receive a QSL card for? An optional QSL column may be added to the Qsos Box with "Pse" or "Tnx" printed as appropriate for each QSO. See Setting Qsos Box Properties for more information.

section.title: Two-Sided Cards
section.para: HamQSLer does not directly support the design and printing of two-sided cards. You could use the following method to create a two-sided card:

listitem.para: Design a QSL card that will serve as the front of your card. Include one or more images, your callsign, and possibly a greeting or your city, etc. Delete other text and the Qsos Box from the card so that they will not be printed.
Design another card that will serve as the back of your card. Include additional images if you wish, your callsign, all other text, and the Qsos Box.
When you print the cards, first print the front of the cards, then reload the cardstock in your printer so that the backside can be printed. Print the back of the card.
